The date when Defence Minister Guido Crosetto publicly reported receiving a suspicious call from a 'friend', prompting public awareness of the AI voice fraud.
The date when Resemble AI reported a global deepfake scam loss of $347 million between January and June 2025, showing a rising trend in AI-related fraud.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which AI voice cloning and deepfake scams have surged, particularly in early 2025, with reports of increasing financial fraud and misuse of synthetic media.

keyTakeAways: AI-generated voices are now indistinguishable from real human voices, especially when trained on extensive voice data.
Deepfake voice scams targeting high-profile individuals have increased, with Italian businessmen being targeted by fake calls from Defence Minister Guido Crosetto.
Only Massimo Moratti, former owner of Inter Milan, made a transfer of money, and he has filed a legal complaint against the fraud.
AI voice cloning technology uses deep learning and natural language processing to mimic pitch, intonation, accent, and even breathing patterns, making fakes highly realistic.

A study by Queen Mary University of London found that 41% of AI-generated voices and 58% of voice clones were mistaken for real human voices, and participants often rated AI voices as more trustworthy.
AI deepfakes are being used to create fake news, scam victims, and sexually explicit content, including child sexual abuse material, leading to global policy responses.
The US and Australia have enacted laws targeting the distribution of AI-generated intimate content, reflecting growing legal and societal concern.
While AI voice technology has positive applications like helping people who cannot speak, its misuse poses serious risks to privacy, identity, and safety.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In early 2025, a wave of AI-powered deepfake voice scams targeted prominent Italian businessmen, with fraudsters impersonating Defence Minister Guido Crosetto to request large financial transfers. The scam, which emerged just after Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni secured the release of journalist Cecilia Sala from Iran, exploited advanced AI voice cloning technology capable of mimicking pitch, accent, and speech patterns so realistically that participants in a research study often mistook AI voices for real ones. Only one businessman, former Inter Milan owner Massimo Moratti, transferred money, which was later frozen by police. Experts, including Nadine Lavan of Queen Mary University of London, note that AI-generated voices are now indistinguishable from real human voices, with participants more likely to trust AI voices. The global rise in deepfake fraud—exceeding $547 million in losses by mid-2025—has prompted policy responses in the US and Australia, including laws banning the distribution of AI-generated intimate images. While AI voice technology has beneficial uses, such as restoring speech for individuals with speech impairments, its misuse in identity theft, fraud, and the creation of harmful content—including child sexual abuse material—poses a growing threat to public safety and trust.
title: AI now sounds more like us – should we be concerned?
